div.p: Greetings. Those who wish you well, brother, out of imprudence, as I indeed judge, intended to help by not helping.
Their effort is not to be disapproved; but they still deserve praise, who also do not wish you ill and saw that you had been thrust into extreme poverty and therefore dissuaded you.
Those who serve the church in Wangens are almost deprived of all resources.
When indeed would you have been freed from this misery? Everyone knows that you are greatly loved and held in high esteem among those with whom you now serve as a minister of Christ.
They would have strongly disapproved of your desertion later, especially since you have scarcely completed two years.
Therefore, it is much more prudent that you still faithfully serve the church to which the Lord has called you.

Good men will not forget you if you continue as you have done so far; indeed, the Lord himself, the consul of Cham, a most distinguished man, also dissuaded this change, but promises well if you always remain the same.
And I too, if I could and were given to live longer, will always remember you.
But also the Lord, who above all is to be regarded, will never fail the faithful.
In this, I wish you well.
Greet Remigius von Schauenstein, whom although I have never seen, I hear is a strong and good man.
Especially greet the excellent old man, the beloved Paul, etc. February 14, 1563.
To the faithful minister of the church in Davos, Tobias Egli, my esteemed colleague and dearest brother.
